messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Advice on Similar Tanto
messages.msgSnippet: As I understand it Kazu-uchi mono were tempered and complete swords. The rules about signatures are general, mediocre works are rarely seen with the full
messages.messageBody:
As I understand it Kazu-uchi mono were tempered and complete
swords. The rules about signatures are general, mediocre works are
rarely seen with the "full" signatures, however sometimes a well made
sword may be seen with the "plain" mei.
> I would also think that a "kazu-uchi tanto"√ù is an
>oxymoron,kazu-uchi works were all katana or wakizashi.Tanto I have
>always been told command more skill and tend to focus the talents of
>the smith, the presence of a "kazu-uchi mei" on one of these would,
>I think, be of little concern. I have seen several excellent
>Kiyomitsu tanto with just a two character mei.

-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Advice on Similar Tanto
messages.msgSnippet: I would be interested in finding the definitive answer for the mass produced swords thing. From what I ve read, the bundled swords didn t even have a hamon
messages.messageBody:
I would be interested in finding the definitive answer for the mass
produced swords thing.

From what I've read, the "bundled swords" didn't even have a hamon (in
some cases? Or in all cases?)

Given that you might destroy your poorly made sword, and a poorly made
sword is even less likely to survive the process, I would think you'd
just heat the whole thing, quench, sharpen, and toss in the bundle.

It doesn't take that long to heat harden the whole thing, plus will not
destroy the sword.

On the signature stuff... Bishu = worse than Bizen I understand to apply
only to Sue Bizen swords.

My *guess* would be that the amount of effort going into cutting the mei
indicates the care taken... Bishu Osafune Sukesada/Kiyomitsu is easier
to carve than Bizen Kuni Osafune Ju Sukesada/Kiyomitsu.

As well as no date...

But for these swords that seem to have reasonably good construction, are
signed Bishu Osafune XX, and have a hamon showing activity... is it fair
to call those mass produced swords?

After all, the workmanship is showing things not associated with mass
production. It's only the signature that is saying something. So is it a
"bad" rule of thumb to judge these exclusively based on signature?

Or are there just different levels to the mass-production. Maybe less
skilled people/apprentices are given the work of making the Bishu
Osafune stuff while the talented guys are taking their time with the
better items?

- darcy

messages.subject: Advice on Similar Tanto
messages.msgSnippet: Hey, may as well jump in here and ask about my tanto also.  Please refer to the Photos section at left, in the NC folder.  The tanto is signed Bishu Osafune
messages.messageBody:
Hey, may as well jump in here and ask about my tanto also. Please
refer to the Photos section at left, in the NC folder. The tanto is
signed Bishu Osafune Kiyo(mitsu?) and Eiroku jyu ichi (nen?) (?)
gatsu hi (1568). Q #1: Is it indeed kazu uchimono? Seems so, given
the Bishu vs. Bizen mei, the date, plus it also has a lot of loose
hada and forging ware. Q #2: Any idea as to which Kiyomitsu made
it? Q #3: Is it common for kazu uchimono of this area and time to
have loads of utsuri and nijuba/sanjuba as does this example? That
is, while the forging was apparently quick and dirty, it appears that
this blade got the full professional tempering treatment. Possibly
the smiths were so used to doing the tempering correctly that they
just did it as a matter of course, even for bundled blades? Thanks
in advance for any and all input!

NC
